data.title: Geology, petrology and radiochronology of Nuku Hiva (Marquesas islands, French Polynesia)
data.meta_description: With a surface area of 330 km^2, Nuku Hiva is the largest island in the Marquesas archipelago, which is made up of a 400-km-long linear chain of Neogene volcanoes. Situated at 10^oS and 140^oW, the Marquesas are among the most isolated islands in the Pacific, at a distance of more than 6000 km from the Americas and New Zealand. The geological mapping programme of French Polynesia has made it possible to propose a model for the volcanostructural evolution of Nuku Hiva island. This model is based on field studies supported by geochemical and petrographic analyses of 150 new samples covering the whole of the island. These analyses indicate the existence of a continuous series of lavas with compositions evolving from tholeiitic basalts through to trachytes (D.I. ranging from 45.20 to 62.70). The stratigraphy of the island, as recognized from ground observations, is corroborated by a series of radiometric age determinations by the K/Ar<SUP>*</SUP> method. Thin lava flows from the external shield volcano, primarily tholeiitic in composition (D.I. 45.20--49.50), account for approximately 60% of the rocks making up the emerged part of Nuku Hiva. The build-up of the inner volcano begins with the eruption of tholeiitic lavas, as well as transitional and alkali basalts. These lavas rapidly evolve towards hawaiites (D.I.min=45,50) and mugearites (D.I.max=53.90), which form the major part of the inner volcano. The final stage of activity of the inner volcano is marked by the emplacement of intrusions and flows of benmoreite (D.I.min=54.70) and trachyte (D.I.max=62.70) around Taiohae Bay and at the head of the valley of Hakaui. Despite the intense weathering produced by low-latitude meteoric waters, it is possible to identify the traces of three calderas. The first caldera, which affects the external volcano, is horseshoe shaped and has led to the slumping of the southern part of the volcano shield into the sea. This created the space necessary for the accumulation of the inner volcano, which abuts against the walls of the first caldera. At the end of its construction, the first caldera was affected by two imbricated collapse structures centred on Taiohae Bay. The trace of these faults is picked out by the emplacement of intrusions and dome-flows that mark the end of the volcano's activity.
data.text:
Abstract

With a surface area of 330 km^2, Nuku Hiva is the largest island in the Marquesas archipelago, which is made up of a 400-km-long linear chain of Neogene volcanoes. Situated at 10^oS and 140^oW, the Marquesas are among the most isolated islands in the Pacific, at a distance of more than 6000 km from the Americas and New Zealand. The geological mapping programme of French Polynesia has made it possible to propose a model for the volcanostructural evolution of Nuku Hiva island. This model is based on field studies supported by geochemical and petrographic analyses of 150 new samples covering the whole of the island. These analyses indicate the existence of a continuous series of lavas with compositions evolving from tholeiitic basalts through to trachytes (D.I. ranging from 45.20 to 62.70). The stratigraphy of the island, as recognized from ground observations, is corroborated by a series of radiometric age determinations by the K/Ar* method. Thin lava flows from the external shield volcano, primarily tholeiitic in composition (D.I. 45.20--49.50), account for approximately 60% of the rocks making up the emerged part of Nuku Hiva. The build-up of the inner volcano begins with the eruption of tholeiitic lavas, as well as transitional and alkali basalts. These lavas rapidly evolve towards hawaiites (D.I.min=45,50) and mugearites (D.I.max=53.90), which form the major part of the inner volcano. The final stage of activity of the inner volcano is marked by the emplacement of intrusions and flows of benmoreite (D.I.min=54.70) and trachyte (D.I.max=62.70) around Taiohae Bay and at the head of the valley of Hakaui. Despite the intense weathering produced by low-latitude meteoric waters, it is possible to identify the traces of three calderas. The first caldera, which affects the external volcano, is horseshoe shaped and has led to the slumping of the southern part of the volcano shield into the sea. This created the space necessary for the accumulation of the inner volcano, which abuts against the walls of the first caldera. At the end of its construction, the first caldera was affected by two imbricated collapse structures centred on Taiohae Bay. The trace of these faults is picked out by the emplacement of intrusions and dome-flows that mark the end of the volcano's activity.
